hackathon-description-text: CU HACKS 2 is the Cupertino Library’s FREE, overnight hack-a-thon event for teenage participants and is part of the Santa Clara County Library District’s Teen Summer Reading Challenge 2016. CU Hacks 2 is scheduled for June 11 - 12, 2016.
hackathon-eligibility: Participants must be between the ages of 14 - 19
hackathon-requirements:
ALL CU HACKS 2 Projects Submissions Must:
• Be your own work
• Be a finished product
• Can be anything that requires coding as the majority of the work involved (i.e. creating iphone/android apps, a website, a hardware hack, etc.)
• No malicious hacking allowed! No DDOSing the network, breaking into an existing product (i.e. facebook), etc.
hackathon-rules:
CU HACKS RULES
Whoa now! Before you start pounding away at the keyboard and channeling your inner Steve Jobs, let’s go over the ground rules.
• All CU HACK participants must be between the ages of 14 - 19 years old.
• All CU HACK participants must have parental signatures on the SCCLD Permission form.
• All CU HACK participants must have parental signatures on the SCCLD Photo Release form.
• All participants must be registered through the library’s webpage in order to participate.
• All participants must be present at CU HACKS to work on a project for submission.
• No remote participants allowed.
• No coding is permitted before the official start of the event
• Teams must consist of between 1 - 4 people. No exceptions
• No one will be allowed to leave the library premises during the event unless accompanied by a parent/guardian and staff is notified ahead of time
• Stealing source code from other participants is not allowed
• Judges will have the final ruling on prize distribution and category winners

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Compatible with Xbox Playstation Gameboy Nintendo Wii MP3s DVDs and more.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: X Rocker 5127401 Pedestal Video Gaming Chair, Wireless , Black

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Intelligent Orientation Control (IOC) system The Syma X8G has the Intelligent Orientation Control (IOC) function. Usually, the forward direction of a flying multi-rotor is the same as the nose direction. By using IOC, the forward direction has nothing to do with nose direction. This lessens the steepness of the learning curve and allows the pilot to enjoy flight while slowly learning each specific orientation of the quadcopter.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Cheerwing Syma X8G 2.4Ghz 4CH RC Headless Quadcopter Drone with 8MP HD Camera, Extra 2pcs 2000mAh Batteries

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Our thinnest tablet yet and almost 2x more durable than the latest iPad Mini
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Amazon Fire HD 8 Tablet, 8" HD Display, Wi-Fi, 8 GB

hackathon-location-google-maps: https://maps.google.com/?q=10800 Torre Ave, Cupertino, CA 95014, USA
hackathon-description-header: CU HACKS 2 is the Cupertino Library’s FREE, overnight hack-a-thon event for teens where the next generation of programmers join together to bring their coolest ideas to life.
